title: WIP: New serialization
body:
(Fixes #829)

Regarding the previous todo list:

- [x] documentation is missing for many functions
- [x] handle usual shared variables (not created by bricks)
- [x] handle shared variables without names
- [x] handle variables with duplicate names
- [x] support CUDA

What I still need to do:

- [ ] write the tests
- [ ] complete the docstring
- [ ] fix the hack in add_to_dump
- [x] add the protocol to pickle

Finally, when we move to the current blocks version:

- [ ] adapt existing interface
- [ ] adapt the tempdir

Finally, I don't really like the name `parameters`, because it is not general enough. It is true that in practice we will use it to save the parameters of our models separately, but I think it would be better to use something like `separated_parts` and `separated_shared_variables`. The name is long though.

title: WIP: Batch normalization
body:
This continues the work done on #513. Current status:

Gammas/betas no longer need to be provided by the user, but the default initialization can be overridden with the given_gammas/given_betas kwargs. The initial population statistics can be similarly specified. These keyword arguments should be dicts with variables for keys and initial values for values.

The previous version of apply_batch_normalization had a use_population keyword argument that allowed per-variable switching between batch/population statistics. If necessary, this can now be done by multiple calls to apply_batch_normalization.

To get from here to a fully functional BN implementation, we need to think about how to save/load the BN parameters. The gammas and betas are already recognized by blocks as parameters, and so the user could construct the given_gammas/given_betas argument from a saved model's parameter dictionary (maybe a helper function for this would be convenient). The population statistics however aren't saved/loaded yet when they definitely should be as they are part of the knowledge the model has acquired. I am open to suggestions on how to do this.

The gist at https://gist.github.com/cooijmanstim/8b570f38cbb174ab0438 shows an example of the new usage.

title: Adding a positive bias to the LSTM forget gate
body: According to the "Rafal Jozefowicz, Wojciech Zaremba, Ilya Sutskever, An Empirical Exploration of Recurrent Network Architectures, JMLR 2015" the LSTM with large forget bias outperformed all available recurrent units in almost all tasks: "But most importantly, we determined that adding a positive bias to the forget gate greatly improves the performance of the LSTM. Given that this technique the simplest to implement, we recommend it for every LSTM implementation". The pull request contains implementation of the technique.

title: Prevent blocks-extras config from crashing things
body:
This will at least stop things from crashing, but it'll give warnings as long as the user never imports `blocks.extras`, which is not ideal. The alternative is to add something like this to `config.py`:
```python
try:
    import blocks.extras
except ImportError
    pass
```
But I'm not a big fan of that either
